question: How to draw a cartoon dog? Use visual steps suitable for beginners and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin the dog cartoon outline by drawing his face. Outline the eyes using curved lines. Extend the side of one eye to form the top of the long snout or muzzle. 2. 2. At the end of the snout, draw a circle. This is the dog’s nose. Use curved lines to trace the side of the dog’s face and his forehead. Above the eyes, use curved lines to enclose the pointed eyebrows 3. 3. Draw the dog’s open, smiling mouth. Below the nose, draw a wide, curved “W” shaped line. Let it meet the nose on one side. On the other, extend the arm of the “W” all the way to the corner of the mouth. Below this, use curved lines to outline the lower jaw, the inside of the mouth, and the tongue. Contour the corner of the mouth with short lines. At the front of the snout, draw two small, triangular teeth. 4. 4. Use curved lines to enclose the rounded shapes of the dog’s ears. Then, use long curved lines to trace the top of the head, neck, and side of the body. 5. 5. Extend a long curved line below the lower jaw to form the chest. Then, use a pair of long curved lines to draw the leg. At the bottom, use overlapping curved lines to create the toes and enclose the paw. 6. 6. Contour the chest with a curved line and draw the remaining front leg. Again, use curved lines. Those at the toes should overlap. 7. 7. Draw the rear leg, bent into a sitting position, using curved lines. Again the toes should utilize overlapping curved lines. 8. 8. Draw the remaining leg of the sitting dog. Use curved lines for the back, the bent leg, and the round paw. Band the paw with short lines. 9. 9. Complete your dog cartoon outline by drawing his wagging tail. Extend two curved lines from the dog’s hip and allow them to meet at a sharp point. Beside the tail, sketch a hatch mark pattern using curved lines to simulate the motion of the tail. 10. Color your cartoon dog. We’ve shaded ours dark brown like a chocolate labrador dog.

Front legs & paws

question: How to draw a rocket ship? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin by drawing a curved line. This will form one side of the rocket ship. 2. 2. Draw another curved line mirroring the first. They should meet in a gentle curve on the top end, but they should not connect on the bottom end. This outlines the body, or fuselage, of the rocket. 3. 3. Enclose the open end of the rocket using a pair of straight lines. 4. 4. Band the nose cone with two pairs of curved parallel lines. 5. 5. Draw portholes, or small windows, along the side of the rocket. To do so, draw several circles of different sizes. 6. 6. Draw the rocket's fin. First, draw a straight line from the tail of the rocket to its middle. Then, draw curved lines downward from each end of the straight line. Allow the curved lines to meet at a gentle point. 7. 7. Erase guide lines from the fin. 8. 8. Draw the rocket's second fin. To do so, extend two curved lines from the top side of the rocket - one emerging from the middle of the ship, the other from its base. Allow the lines to meet at a gentle point. 9. 9. Draw the flames, called exhaust, coming from the rocket's nozzle, or base. Use a series of short curved lines that meet in jagged points to draw a rounded triangular shape. Then, use another series of lines to draw a second layer. Finally, draw the third layer of the exhaust, allowing it to end at a point. 10. Color your rocket. Rockets such as the one in this drawing guide were popular illustrations during the 1950s and 1960s. Some were silver in color, while others had bright red, blue, or other colored markings.

question: How to bake cookies from scratch? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Keep everything cold. If you are using butter in your cookies (and even, to a certain degree, if you aren't) you will want to keep your ingredients refrigerator-cold. This will make your cookies much more firm and keep them from spreading out in the oven. This means that you'll have to warm up the butter enough to work with it by placing it on the counter, rather than in the microwave. Absolutely never melt it in order to mix it into the dough. A great practice is to cool your dough in the fridge for an hour before rolling it out. 2. Always cream butter and sugar. If your recipe calls for butter and doesn't specifically prohibit this practice, you should always "cream" the butter and the sugar first. This is a process by which you mix the two until a sort of paste is formed. 3. Try to use salted butter. Sweet cream butter tends to make cookies taste too sweet. The salt will balance out the sweetness of the cookie just enough to make it taste much better over all. You won't be able to properly taste the salt, but believe us, you'll notice the difference. 4. Change the recipe to alter the final product. If you find a recipe that you love the taste of but want a different texture, it is totally possible to alter the recipe just a bit in order to get exactly what you want! Experiment, or try these tricks: Use cake flour instead of regular flour, shortening instead of butter (or for part of the butter), or about 2 teaspoons of cornstarch along with 4 teaspoons less flour in order to get fluffy, cakey, and softer cookies. Use 2 tablespoons of milk, an extra tablespoon or two of butter, or switch your white sugar for brown to get a crispy cookie. Use melted butter to mix dough and then chill it before baking (undercook a minute or two) to get a chewy cookie. You can also use only yolks, instead of whites. Using a rubber spatula often helps speed up the mixing process if you are not using a machine. 5. Weigh your ingredients. If you find that you still struggle with getting your recipe to turn out right, bake like the pros (and Europeans!) do and weigh your ingredients. Get a good electronic kitchen scale and do your recipe based on weight. This will help ensure the perfect cookie. 6. Use an ice cream scoop to make cookies even. If you want to make sure that every cookie in a batch turns out looking the same, use an ice cream scoop to get perfectly equal balls of dough. 7. Use parchment paper. Skip the Silpat in favor of parchment paper. Silpat can make it difficult for cookies to cook evenly and it also keeps the bottoms from developing that perfect crispness. Parchment paper turns out a much better cookie. 8. Bake on the bottom of your cookie sheet. If you notice that the cookies at the edge of your sheet are prone to getting over cooked, use an Round or oval pan. If you don't have one, improvise and flip the pan over to use the bottom! 9. Know your oven. Every oven is different and it is important for you to know how yours behaves. If you know what to expect, then you can find ways to work around the expected problems. For example, if you notice that cookies on one corner or side bake faster than in another, make sure you turn the pan part-way through the baking process. 10. Start with a cold pan. Put your baking sheet in the fridge to cool before you put each set of cookies on. If you want to save time, you can scoop the dough onto parchment paper and store them in the fridge until they are ready to go out on a cooled pan. This means cooling the pan between each set of 12 too! 11. Don't overbake your cookies. If anything it's better to under-bake them. For the first batch carefully watch them and time for when they get the first hint of brown at the edges. Edge browning usually means you've gone too far, though these cookies are still perfectly good (especially if you like yours crispy!). Once you know how long it takes to reach that point, pull them out maybe 30 seconds before they brown for perfectly soft cookies. If you are using white chocolate chips in your cookies, be careful, as they can burn particularly easily. 12. Let cookies sit on the pan. Let your cookies sit on the pan for a few minutes before taking them off. This will let them firm up on the bottom, making them much easier to remove.

# Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies (from scratch)

**Yield:** ~18 cookies (40–45g each)
**Time:** 20 min prep + 10–12 min bake (per tray)

## Ingredients

* 225 g (1¾ cups) all-purpose flour
* ½ tsp baking soda
* ½ tsp fine salt
* 170 g (¾ cup) unsalted butter, softened (cool room temp)
* 150 g (¾ cup, packed) light brown sugar
* 100 g (½ cup) granulated sugar
* 1 large egg **+** 1 extra yolk (for extra chew)
* 2 tsp vanilla extract
* 200–225 g (1¼–1½ cups) chocolate chips or chopped chocolate

## Equipment

2 mixing bowls, whisk, hand/stand mixer (or sturdy spoon), rubber spatula, cookie scoop or spoons, baking sheet, parchment.

## Steps

1. **Prep oven & pans**
   Preheat to **350°F / 175°C**. Line a baking sheet with parchment.

2. **Dry mix**
   Whisk **flour, baking soda, and salt** in a bowl; set aside.

3. **Cream**
   In a separate bowl, beat **butter + both sugars** on medium until **pale and fluffy (1–2 min)**.

4. **Eggs & vanilla**
   Beat in **egg, then yolk, then vanilla** just until smooth.

5. **Combine**
   Add dry ingredients. Mix on low or fold until **just combined** (no dry streaks; avoid overmixing).

6. **Chocolate**
   Fold in chocolate.

7. **Scoop & (optional) chill**
   Scoop **2 Tbsp (40–45g)** mounds, well-spaced. For thicker cookies, **chill 15–30 min**.

8. **Bake**
   Bake **10–12 min** until **edges are set and lightly golden** and **centers still look soft/puffy**.

9. **Set & cool**
   Cool on the sheet **5 min**, then transfer to a rack. They’ll finish setting as they cool.

## Doneness Cues

* Edges: lightly golden;
* Centers: soft, a touch pale;
* Surface: faint cracks with glossy melted chocolate.

## Pro Tips

* **Temperature matters:** butter should be soft but cool (no oily sheen).
* **Thickness control:** Chill longer for thicker cookies; bake right away for thinner, chewier edges.
* **Wrinkly tops:** Halfway through baking, **rap** the pan once on the rack.

## Variations

* **Browned-Butter:** Brown 170 g butter; cool till just fluid, then proceed. Adds a nutty note (cookies spread a bit more).
* **Nutty Crunch:** Add ½ cup toasted chopped pecans or walnuts.
* **Salted:** Finish with a **pinch of flaky salt** after baking.
* **Oat-Choc Chip:** Swap 50 g (½ cup) of flour for quick oats.

## Troubleshooting

* **Too flat:** Butter too warm; dough under-chilled; oven too cool.
* **Too cakey/dry:** Over-measured flour; overbaked; overmixed.
* **Greasy edges:** Butter too warm; try chilling 30–60 min.

## Storage & Make-Ahead

* **Baked:** Airtight at room temp **3–4 days**.
* **Dough balls:** Freeze on a tray, then bag; bake from frozen **12–14 min** at 350°F.

question: How to clean eyeglasses without scratches or streaks? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Wash your hands before cleaning your glasses. Wash up for 20 seconds with lotion-free soap and warm water. You’ll need to make sure your hands are free of dirt, grease, and grime before cleaning your glasses. 2. Rinse your glasses with warm water. Run a gentle stream of tap water over your glasses. Rotate them to wet both sides of each lens, the frame, and earpieces. Hot water is bad for lenses, protective coatings, and the frame, so be sure to use warm water. 3. Use your fingertips to carefully lather them with dish soap. Add a small drop of lotion-free dish soap to each lens. Make gentle circular motions with your fingertips to lather the soap over both sides of your lenses, around the frame, and down each earpiece. 4. Clean the nose pads with a cotton swab or soft toothbrush. Use gentle pressure as you scrub the nose pads and the crevices between them and the frame. # How to Clean Eyeglasses (no scratches, no streaks)

## What you’ll need

* Clean, lotion-free hand soap

## Step-by-step

# Text-only steps (for a standard drip coffee maker)

## Before you start

* Unplug the machine and let it cool.
* Check your manual; some brands discourage vinegar—use citric acid instead if so.
* Remove any charcoal/water filter from the reservoir (replace after cleaning).

## Quick clean (after each brew)

1. Discard grounds and the paper filter.
2. Wash the carafe, brew basket, lid, and reusable mesh filter in warm, soapy water; rinse and air-dry.
3. Wipe the exterior and warming plate with a damp cloth; leave the lid open to dry.

## Deep clean & descale (every 1–3 months, or ~every 40 brews)

1. **Empty & prep:** Reassemble the empty basket; place the empty carafe on the plate.
2. **Mix descaler:**

   * Option A: Fill the reservoir with a **1:1 mix of white vinegar and water**.
   * Option B (vinegar-free): **1–2 tsp citric acid per cup (250 mL) of warm water**, stir to dissolve, then fill the reservoir.
3. **Start brew & soak:** Run a brew cycle until the carafe is **about halfway** full, then **pause** the machine for **30 minutes** to dissolve mineral buildup.
4. **Finish brew:** Resume and complete the cycle; discard the hot solution carefully.
5. **Rinse cycles:** Fill the reservoir with plain water and run **2–3 full cycles**, discarding each carafe, until there’s **no vinegar/citric smell**.
6. **Detail clean:**

   * Wipe the showerhead/spray arm and the area under the brew basket; use a soft brush or toothpick to clear clogged holes.
   * Clean the carafe stains with a paste of **baking soda + a few drops of water**; rinse thoroughly.
7. **Reinstall filter:** If you use a charcoal water filter, install a fresh one.

## Safety & tips

* **Never use bleach** or abrasive scrubbers inside the machine.
* Hard water? Descale **monthly**; soft water can go **every 2–3 months**.

* **Stabilized, enclosed capsules:** Riders travel in sealed, climate-controlled pods that keep the floor level as the wheel turns, protecting people from wind and motion.
* **Slow, controlled operation:** The wheel rotates at a gentle, steady pace so boarding and disembarking are calm and orderly, with operators able to pause movement when needed.

question: How to do calf raises? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Stand on the edge of a stair step, or a step of any kind (as long as it's in a safe environment). Make sure the step is not very far up and close to the ground. You don't want to fall too far should you lose your balance . 2. Stand straight, with your tailbone tucked in. Engage your core by pulling in your upper ribs and belly. Make sure that the balls of your feet are solidly planted on the edge of the step. Your heels should be over the edge. If you feel unstable, or like you're losing your balance, practice this method with a wall or railing near by. Place your hands on the wall or the railing. 3. Lift your heels until you're standing on your tippy toes. Distribute most of your weight onto the balls of your feet, and keep your legs straight. 4. Stay on your tippy toes for two seconds. Then, begin to lower your heels, and move your weight away from the balls of your feet. Lower your heels until they're below the step, or platform. You should be feeling your calf muscles stretch on the downward movement. Repeat this sequence until you feel tired.

# How to Run in High Heels — Text Steps

1. Choose the right heels

* Pick a stable pair: block heel or wedge, 2–3 in (5–7.5 cm), secure ankle strap, good fit.
* Add non-slip sole grips if the bottoms are slick.

2. Prep & warm up (1–2 min)

* Ankle circles (both directions), calf raises, gentle hamstring/calf stretch.
* Check straps/buckles are snug.

3. Posture setup

* Stand tall: ears over shoulders, shoulders over hips, ribs stacked, neutral pelvis.
* Engage your core lightly; look where you’re going (not at your feet).

4. Start with short, quick steps

* Keep strides small to stay balanced.
* Aim for a light, quick cadence rather than long reaches.

5. Soft forefoot landing

* Touch down gently near the ball of the foot, then roll through—avoid stabbing the heel first.
* Keep toes pointing forward; don’t let ankles collapse inward.

6. Use compact arm swing

* Elbows ~90°, swing close to the body to counterbalance without twisting your torso.

7. Pick safe surfaces

* Prefer smooth, dry, even ground.
* Avoid grates, cobblestones, grass, wet tile, and steep slopes.
* If you must cross hazards, slow to a walk.

8. Braking & turning

* To slow: shorten steps, keep torso tall, don’t lean back.
* For turns: take several tiny steps (no sharp pivots on a planted heel).

9. Emergency stop & recovery

* If you wobble: plant both feet shoulder-width, knees soft, lower your heels toward flat, then reset.
* If a heel catches: stop, step back out, don’t yank forward.

10. Cool down & care

* Walk it off for 30–60 seconds, stretch calves/arches.
* Inspect tips/heel caps; swap to flats if feet feel fatigued.

### Practice Drills (build skill before full running)

* March in place in heels (30–60s).
* Walk–jog intervals: 10–20m jog, 20–30m walk; repeat 4–6x.
* Figure-8 weaving around two cones/chairs to train controlled turns.

### Safety Notes

* Running in heels increases risk of ankle/knee injury—only do brief sprints when necessary.
* Never run in very high, narrow stilettos or loose shoes.
* Carry foldable flats as a backup.

question: How to do tree pose in yoga? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Place Feet Under Your Hips. Stand with your feet about shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent. Roll your shoulders up, back, and down. Pause to feel your strength here, making sure you have equal weight in each foot and that you’re breathing to protect your back. 2. Move One Foot to the Side and Lift Your Heel. Move your left foot out to the side a few inches, allowing your toes to point out about 45 degrees. When you’re ready, lift your left heel so that you’re balancing on one leg. Continue breathing here for as long as you’d like. 3. Bring Your Foot In. When you feel ready, bring your left foot in to meet your right so it’s like a kickstand. Your left knee remains turned out to the side. Root down into your feet, and place your hands on your hips. 4. Grow Your Tree. When you feel ready, extend your hands overhead like tree branches. Breathe here for three to 10 breaths. Reverse the movement to return to mountain pose, then repeat on the opposite side.

question: How to Do Free Squats? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Bend your knees. In essence, "squatting" simply means to bend your knees, bringing your backside closer to the floor. For best results, try bending your knees to a 90-degree angle, then standing back up. [1] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 2. Keep your knees behind your toes. This protects your knees and back and helps you achieve maximum results. When you move into a squat, bend your knees so that they move directly over your feet, without going further than your toes. [3] X Expert Source Dean Theriot Personal Trainer Expert Interview 3. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart. For a standard free squat, start by keeping your feet under your shoulders. This help to avoid stress on your knees. 4. Angle your feet for plié squats. A plié squat is a free squat done with a wide stance. For these, it is important to angle your feet out and to bend your knees so they move directly over your feet. Begin by doing these at only a half-range of motion, and work up to getting your knee bends to 90 degrees. 5. Stop at the bottom. After you build up some leg strength, you may begin to "break 90," or allow your squat to deepen more than a 90-degree bend in your knees. However, it is important to stop when your thighs lightly come into contact with your calves. Going beyond this can place unnecessary stress on your knees.
generated_text:
# Free (Bodyweight) Squat — Text Guide

Follow these clear, safe steps. If anything hurts (sharp pain), stop and adjust range or seek a pro.

## 1) Set Your Stance

* Feet about shoulder-width apart (a little wider or narrower based on comfort).
* Toes turned slightly out (≈5–20°) so knees can track over them.
* Distribute weight through the whole foot (heel + big toe + little toe). Look ahead.

## 2) Brace

* Take a deep breath “360°” into your belly and sides.
* Gently lock ribs down as if prepping for a cough; keep spine neutral.
* Set shoulders down/back. Lightly squeeze glutes.

## 3) Initiate: Hips Back, Knees Out

* Start the squat by sending the hips slightly back, then let the knees bend.
* Let knees track in line with the toes (don’t cave inward).
* Reach your arms forward a bit for balance if helpful.

## 4) Descend Under Control

* Lower smoothly; keep chest proud and back neutral.
* Keep heels flat; stay balanced over mid-foot.
* Go as low as **your** mobility allows—aim for thighs parallel to the floor or lower without losing your brace.

## 5) Check the Bottom Position

* Knees track over toes; don’t collapse inward.
* Weight balanced (not on toes only; heels stay down).
* Avoid excessive pelvis tuck (“butt wink”). If it appears, stop just above that range.

## 6) Drive Up

* Push the floor away through mid-foot/heels.
* Stand up by extending hips and knees together (no shooting hips up first).
* Keep knees tracking over toes; exhale through the sticking point.

## 7) Finish Tall

* Stand tall with hips and knees fully extended.
* Reset your breath/bracing before the next rep.

---

## Breathing Cue (Simple)

* **Inhale & brace** before you descend → **exhale** as you drive up.
* For heavier sets, you can hold a gentle brace until you pass the hardest point, then exhale.

## Common Mistakes → Quick Fixes

* **Heels lift:** Widen stance slightly; slow down; work ankle mobility; try a small heel lift (5–10 mm).
* **Knees cave in:** Think “spread the floor” or “push knees toward pinky toes.”
* **Back rounds:** Re-brace; keep chest proud; shorten depth slightly; include core work.
* **Leaning too far forward:** Bring heels under hips; use counterbalance arms; keep gaze forward.
* **Bouncing/relaxing at bottom:** Pause briefly; keep tension.

## Regressions (Easier)

* **Box/Chair Squat:** Tap a box/chair behind you for depth control.
* **Supported Squat:** Hold a doorframe/TRX for assistance.
* **Heel-elevated Squat:** Place thin plates under heels to ease ankle demand.

## Helpful Progressions (Harder)

* **Goblet Squat (light weight)** for counterbalance and torso position.
* **Tempo Squat:** 3-sec lower, no bounce, smooth up.
* **Pause Squat:** 1–2 sec hold at the bottom with tension.
* **Split Squat / Pistol to Box** for single-leg control.

## Suggested Sets & Reps

* Beginners: **3 × 8–10 reps**, rest 60–90 s.
* Warm-up: 5 min light cardio + 2–3 easy ramp-up sets.

> Goal: Smooth, controlled reps with consistent depth and balance. Quality first; load later.

question: How to do side crunches? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Lie down on the floor. Lie down on a fitness mat. Lie with your back flat on the ground, legs together and knees bent. Keep in mind that this movement is not recommended for anyone who has ever had a back problem. This movement can be made easier by placing your hands and arms lower on your body (crossing arms in front of your chest) or harder, by placing your hands and arms past your head (arms extended above your head). 2. Turn your legs to one side. With your knees remaining bent, turn at your waist and bring both of your legs to one side of your body, down to the floor. Your legs should be lying on top of each other. As you bring your legs down to the floor, keep your shoulder blades and the upper part of your back flat on the floor. Your rib cage should be down and not flared out in this position. If you overextend, you risk straining your upper back. [4] X Expert Source Brendon Rearick Personal Trainer & Strength Coach Expert Interview 3. Crunch to your side. Place your hands behind or at the sides of your head. Flex your abdominal muscles, and lift your shoulders off the floor. Be sure to keep your shoulders straight and level just as you would for a normal crunch. Hold the position for a moment, then release your constricted abdominal muscles to slowly bring your shoulders back down to the mat. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Do not pull at your head and neck to complete the crunch. Your hands are merely resting near your head as you contract your abdominal muscles to lift yourself up and crunch. [7] X Expert Source Brendon Rearick Personal Trainer & Strength Coach Expert Interview Exhale as you crunch and inhale as you return to your starting position. Then, repeat. Breathing properly will put your diaphragm in a better position for abdominal work. [8] X Expert Source Brendon Rearick Personal Trainer & Strength Coach Expert Interview 4. Complete your crunches on the other side of your body. Once you have completed one set of crunches on one side of your body (about 10–15 reps), turn your legs over to do the crunches on other side of your body. It’s recommended to do this exercise 1–3 sets on each side, 2–3 times a week.

# Side Crunch (Side-Lying Oblique Crunch) — Text Steps

1. Set up

* Lie on your **right side** on a mat.
* Bend knees about **90°** and stack hips, knees, and ankles.
* Right forearm on the floor for balance; **left hand** lightly behind your head (don’t pull your neck).
* Keep ribs “down” and neck neutral.

2. Brace

* Take a breath in.
* Gently **brace your core** as if preparing for a light poke, keeping hips stacked and elbow open.

3. Crunch up

* **Exhale** and bring your **left ribcage toward your left hip**.
* Lift both shoulders a few inches; keep elbow wide and gaze forward.
* Knees and legs stay quiet—movement comes from your **obliques**, not from tugging the head.

4. Pause

* Hold the top position for **1 second**, keep breathing softly, feel the side squeeze.

5. Lower with control

* **Inhale** and lower your shoulders back to the start without collapsing. Maintain tension.

6. Repeat & switch sides

* Do **8–15 controlled reps**, then **flip to your left side** to work the right obliques.
* Aim for **2–3 sets per side**.

### Form tips & common mistakes

* Keep hips stacked; don’t roll backward.
* Don’t yank on your head—your hand just supports.
* Small range is fine; prioritize **slow, controlled** reps.
* If you feel your neck more than your side, reduce range and press your tongue lightly to the roof of your mouth to help stabilize.

### Make it easier

* Place top hand across your chest instead of behind your head.
* Keep bottom arm straight and use it lightly on the floor for balance.

### Make it harder

* Straighten your legs and keep feet slightly off the floor.
* Add a light dumbbell or small plate held against the side of your ribcage (still no neck pulling).

If you want variations (e.g., **side plank crunch** or **standing side crunch**), say the word and I’ll add those too.

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
RISE-CoT is a reinforcement learning-driven closed-loop pipeline for generating high-quality Chains of Thought (CoTs) from image-annotation pairs. It operates in three steps: (1) Reasoning Generation, where VLMs produce CoTs that justify the given annotation using visual and contextual cues without directly leaking annotation details; (2) Annotation Reconstruction, where the annotation is reconstructed from the generated CoT to verify its sufficiency; (3) Consistency Validation, which defines a reward function to ensure logical independence, format compliance, and reconstruction accuracy. The outputs are high-quality CoTs paired with annotations and confidence scores, forming an enhanced dataset. This enriched dataset can then be used to fine-tune VLMs for interpretable and accurate reasoning in complex image annotation tasks.
Please generate:
	1.	A pipeline diagram showing the closed-loop flow: image + annotation → reasoning generation → annotation reconstruction → consistency validation → reward → enhanced dataset.
	2.	A separate caption summarizing the key idea of the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: Figure 1: RISE-CoT pipeline. The closed-loop framework generates high-quality, visually grounded CoTs by reasoning over image-annotation pairs, reconstructing annotations to validate reasoning, and filtering via consistency-based rewards. This process produces enhanced datasets for fine-tuning VLMs, improving both interpretability and annotation accuracy.

**Caption (text only):**
Overview of **RISE-CoT**, a reinforcement-learning, closed-loop pipeline for generating high-quality Chains of Thought (CoTs) from image–annotation pairs. A VLM first produces a CoT that explains the given annotation without leaking label details (Reasoning Generation). The CoT is then used to **reconstruct** the annotation to test sufficiency (Annotation Reconstruction). A **Consistency Validation** stage scores logical independence, format compliance, and reconstruction accuracy to produce a reward, which both filters data and updates the generator. The loop yields an **enhanced dataset** of *(image, annotation, CoT, confidence)* pairs for fine-tuning interpretable VLMs.

question: What are faults, and how do they cause earthquakes? an image will help explain.
reference_text: Faults are fractures in Earth's crust where blocks of rock move. Movement along faults—like normal, reverse, or strike-slip—can release energy that causes earthquakes. These faults are caused by tectonic forces such as tension, compression, or shear.
generated_text:
Written explanation

What is a fault?
A fault is a fracture in Earth’s brittle crust where two blocks of rock slide past each other. When tectonic forces push, pull, or shear the crust, stress builds along the fault.

How faults cause earthquakes (the stick-slip cycle):
1.	Locked: Rough fault surfaces “stick” due to friction while plate motion keeps stressing them.
2.	Strain builds: Rock around the fault elastically bends and stores energy.
3.	Rupture: When stress exceeds frictional strength, the fault suddenly slips. The break starts at the hypocenter (focus) at depth and spreads along the fault.
4.	Seismic waves: Stored elastic energy radiates as P and S waves that shake the ground. The point on the surface above the focus is the epicenter.
5.	Aftershocks: The crust adjusts to the new positions, producing smaller quakes on or near the same fault.

Main fault types & the stresses that create them:
•	Normal fault (tension/extension): Crust is pulled apart; the hanging wall moves down.
•	Reverse/thrust fault (compression): Crust is squeezed; the hanging wall moves up (common in subduction zones and mountain belts).
•	Strike-slip fault (shear): Blocks slide horizontally past each other (e.g., transform boundaries); motion can be right-lateral or left-lateral.

Why some places shake more:
Most large earthquakes occur at plate boundaries where stress accumulates fastest: subduction zones (big thrust quakes), continental collisions (reverse faults), and major transforms (strike-slip).

Image generated separately above: labeled diagram showing a fault plane, the earthquake cycle with hypocenter/epicenter and waves, plus normal/reverse/strike-slip fault insets.

question: What is a ray in optics and what are the main types of rays used in ray diagrams? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows Ray (optics). In optics, a ray is an idealized model of light, obtained by choosing a line that is perpendicular to the wave fronts of the actual light, and that points in the direction of energy flow. Rays are used to model the propagation of light through an optical system by dividing the real light field up into discrete rays that can be computationally propagated through the system by the techniques of ray tracing. All three rays should meet at the same point. The Principal Ray or Chief Ray in an optical system is the meridional ray that starts at the edge of the object and passes through the center of the aperture stop. This ray crosses the optical axis at the locations of the pupils. The Central Ray is perpendicular to infrared radiation. The Focal Ray is drawn from the tip of the object through (or towards) the focal point, reflecting off the mirror parallel to the principal axis.

# Written explanation

**What is a ray (in optics)?**
A ray is an idealized line that shows the direction light energy travels. In geometric optics we treat light as straight-line rays that are perpendicular to wavefronts and that obey the rules of **reflection** (angle in = angle out) and **refraction** (Snell’s law) at boundaries.

**Main types of rays you see in ray diagrams**

1. **Incident ray** – the incoming ray that strikes a surface or boundary.
2. **Reflected ray** – the ray that bounces off a mirror; its angle to the normal equals the incident angle.
3. **Refracted (transmitted) ray** – the ray that passes into a new medium and bends according to Snell’s law.
4. **Principal rays** – standard, easy-to-trace rays used to locate images with thin lenses and spherical mirrors:

* **For thin lenses**

  * **Parallel (P) ray:** parallel to the principal axis; after the lens it passes through the focal point (F) (converging lens) or appears to come from (F) (diverging lens).
  * **Focal (F) ray:** aimed toward the focal point before the lens; emerges parallel to the axis (roles swap for diverging lenses).
  * **Central/Chief (O) ray:** passes through the optical center and continues essentially undeviated.

* **For spherical mirrors**

  * **Parallel (P) ray:** parallel to the axis; reflects through (F) (concave) or appears to come from (F) behind the mirror (convex).
  * **Focal (F) ray:** goes through (F); reflects parallel to the axis.
  * **Center-of-curvature (C) ray:** goes through the center of curvature; reflects back on itself.

In diagrams, **solid lines** usually show real rays; **dashed extensions** show virtual rays that appear to originate from a point.

question: I keep mixing up the layers of Earth's atmosphere. Can you walk me through them and show how they change with altitude? Provide an image and explain.
reference_text: The Earth has five different layers in its atmosphere. The atmosphere layers vary by temperature. As the altitude in the atmosphere increases, the air temperature changes. The lowest layer is the troposphere, it gets some of its heat from the sun. However, it gets most of its heat from the Earth's surface. The troposphere is also the shortest layer of the atmosphere. It holds 75 percent of all the gas molecules in the atmosphere. The air is densest in this layer.
generated_text:
# Text (explanation)
Here’s a quick walkthrough of each atmospheric layer, from the ground up, and how temperature changes with height. (Use the diagram above as the visual.)

**1) Troposphere (\~0–8 km at poles; \~0–18 km at tropics)**

* **What it is:** The weather layer—clouds, storms, and most water vapor.
* **Temperature trend:** **Decreases** with altitude (air expands and cools).
* **Top boundary:** **Tropopause** (often around −50 to −60 °C); its height varies with latitude and season.

**2) Stratosphere (\~10–50 km)**

* **What it is:** Home of the **ozone layer**; commercial jets often cruise in the lower stratosphere (smooth, stable air).
* **Temperature trend:** **Increases** with altitude because ozone absorbs UV sunlight and warms this layer.
* **Top boundary:** **Stratopause** (temperature peaks near 0 °C).

**3) Mesosphere (\~50–85 km)**

* **What it is:** Where many **meteors burn up**; very thin, cold air.
* **Temperature trend:** **Decreases** with altitude (little ozone heating, strong radiative cooling).
* **Top boundary:** **Mesopause**—the **coldest** part of the atmosphere (often \~−90 °C).

**4) Thermosphere (\~85–600+ km)**

* **What it is:** Very thin gas that’s strongly affected by the Sun; overlaps the **ionosphere**, where **auroras** occur and radio signals refract.
* **Temperature trend:** **Increases sharply** with altitude (atoms absorb energetic solar radiation); kinetic temperatures can be very high, though the air is too thin to feel “hot.”

**5) Exosphere (\~600–10,000 km)**

* **What it is:** The outer fringe where atoms can escape to space; satellites orbit here (and in the upper thermosphere).
* **Temperature trend:** Stays **high** in kinetic terms, but particle density is extremely low.

---

## How key properties change with altitude

* **Pressure & density:** Drop off **exponentially**—half the atmosphere’s mass is below \~5–6 km; \~99% is below \~30 km.
* **Temperature profile:** Alternates with altitude due to different **heating mechanisms**

 * Cooling in the **troposphere** (expansion) → warming in the **stratosphere** (ozone UV absorption) → cooling in the **mesosphere** → warming in the **thermosphere** (solar extreme-UV absorption).
* **Composition:** Below \~80–100 km is the **homosphere** (well-mixed composition). Above that, lighter gases become more common (start of the **heterosphere**).
* **Ionosphere:** Not a separate “layer” by altitude alone; it **overlaps** the mesosphere/thermosphere (\~60–1,000 km) and is defined by ionization from solar radiation (important for auroras and radio).

question: I don't understand how the respiratory system removes dust and particles. Can you show me what happens inside the lungs? Provide a diagram and explain.
reference_text: The diagram shows the parts of the respiratory system. The human respiratory system is a series of organs responsible for taking in oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide. As we breathe, oxygen enters the nose or mouth and passes the sinuses, which are hollow spaces in the skull. Sinuses help regulate the temperature and humidity of the air we breathe. The trachea, also called the windpipe, filters the air that is inhaled, according to the American Lung Association. It branches into the bronchi, which are two tubes that carry air into each lung. The bronchial tubes are lined with tiny hairs called cilia. Cilia move back and forth, carrying mucus up and out. Mucus, a sticky fluid, collects dust, germs and other matter that has invaded the lungs. We expel mucus when we sneeze, cough, spit or swallow.
generated_text:
Here’s the **text explanation** (kept separate from the diagram):

# How your lungs clear dust & particles

**1) Filters at the entrance (nose & throat).**

* Nasal hairs and the twists/turns of the nasal passages slow air and catch big bits of dust.
* Sticky **mucus** lines the surfaces and traps particles before they reach the lungs.

**2) The mucus trap + cilia conveyor.**

* The airways (trachea and bronchi) are carpeted with tiny hair-like **cilia** sitting in a thin watery layer.
* Above them is a sticky **mucus gel** where dust, pollen, and microbes get stuck.
* Cilia beat in coordinated waves, pushing the mucus blanket **upward toward the throat**. This is the **mucociliary escalator**.

**3) What happens to the trapped stuff.**

* When the mucus reaches the throat, you **swallow** it. Stomach acid and enzymes break down most contaminants.
* If there’s a lot of irritation, sensors trigger a **cough or sneeze**, which blasts mucus and particles out.

**4) Deep areas without cilia: the alveoli.**

* The tiny air sacs (alveoli) handle gas exchange and **don’t have cilia**.
* Here, roaming **alveolar macrophages** (patrolling immune cells) **eat** fine particles and microbes.
* What they collect is carried away via the mucociliary escalator (after they crawl to ciliated regions) or through **lymphatic drainage**.

**5) Size matters (where particles tend to land).**

* **Large** (> ~10 μm): mostly stopped in the **nose/throat**.
* **Medium** (~2.5–10 μm): settle in the **trachea/bronchi**, cleared by cilia.
* **Fine** (< ~2.5 μm): can reach the **alveoli**, handled by macrophages.
* **Gases/ultrafine** may be absorbed or exhaled.

**6) When the system struggles.**

* **Dry air, dehydration, smoking, or pollutants** can thicken or paralyze mucus/cilia.
* Certain conditions (e.g., **asthma**, **chronic bronchitis**, **cystic fibrosis**, or **primary ciliary dyskinesia**) reduce clearance, so particles linger and infections are more likely.

**Quick recap:** your airways trap particles in mucus, **cilia sweep** that mucus upward, and **cough/sneeze or swallowing** removes it; deep in the lungs, **macrophages** finish the cleanup.

question: How are covalent bonds formed in a carbon dioxide molecule (CO₂)? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows the covalent bonds in a carbon dioxide molecule. A covalent bond is a chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms. The carbon dioxide molecule consists of two oxygen atoms and one carbon atom with the chemical formula of CO₂. At the outermost shell of the carbon atom, there are 4 electrons. Each oxygen atom shares 2 electrons with the carbon atom. So, it completes the outermost shell of the carbon atom with 8 total electrons.
generated_text:
# Written explanation

In CO₂, covalent bonds form by **sharing electron pairs** so that each atom reaches an octet:

* **Valence electrons:** Carbon has 4; each oxygen has 6.
* **Sharing to fill octets:** Carbon shares **two pairs** with each oxygen, creating **two C=O double bonds**. Each double bond consists of **one sigma (σ) bond** and **one pi (π) bond**.
* **How the σ bonds form:** Carbon **sp-hybridizes**, producing two linear sp orbitals 180° apart. Each sp orbital overlaps end-to-end with a hybrid orbital on an oxygen to form a σ bond.
* **How the π bonds form:** The unhybridized **p orbitals** on carbon and on each oxygen overlap **side-by-side**, making a π bond above and below the σ bond axis.
* **Geometry & lone pairs:** The sp hybridization gives the molecule a **linear** shape (O=C=O, 180°). Carbon has **no lone pairs**; each oxygen retains **two lone pairs**.
* **Result:** Two equivalent C=O double bonds hold the atoms together; although each C–O bond is polar, the molecule is **overall nonpolar** due to its linear symmetry.

(See the generated image above.)

question: I get confused about the structure of the respiratory system. What are all the parts and how does air travel through them? Provide a diagram and explain.
reference_text: The diagram shows the structures of the respiratory system. They include the nose, trachea, lungs, and diaphragm. The diaphragm is a large, sheet-like muscle below the lungs. When you inhale, air enters the respiratory system through your nose and ends up in your lungs, where gas exchange with the blood takes place. In the nose, mucus and hairs trap any dust or other particles in the air. The air is also warmed and moistened so it wont harm delicate tissues of the lungs. Next, air passes through the pharynx, a passageway that is shared with the digestive system. From the pharynx, the air passes next through the larynx, or voice box. After the larynx, air moves into the trachea, or wind pipe. This is a long tube that leads down to the lungs in the chest. In the chest, the trachea divides as it enters the lungs to form the right and left bronchi (bronchus, singular). These passages are covered with mucus and tiny hairs called cilia. The mucus traps any remaining particles in the air. The cilia move and sweep the particles and mucus toward the throat so they can be expelled from the body. Air passes from the bronchi into smaller passages called bronchioles. The bronchioles end in clusters of tiny air sacs called alveoli (alveolus, singular). The alveoli in the lungs are where gas exchange between the air and blood takes place. Shown also is the rib (or ribs) the protect the lungs and other vital organs within the chest.
generated_text:
# Text Explanation (separate from the image)

## Big picture

Your respiratory system is a branching network that conducts air to millions of tiny sacs (alveoli) where gas exchange happens. It’s often divided into:

* **Upper respiratory tract:** nose/nostrils, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and pharynx (throat).
* **Lower respiratory tract:** larynx (voice box), trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, and lungs (ending in alveoli).
* **Supporting structures:** chest wall, **diaphragm**, intercostal muscles, and the **pleura** (the double-layer lining around the lungs).

## The parts, in order

1. **Nostrils (nares) & nasal vestibule** – entry points. Nose hairs and mucus trap dust; blood-rich lining warms and humidifies air.
   *(If you breathe through your mouth, the first steps below are bypassed.)*
2. **Nasal cavity & turbinates** – twisty shelves that swirl air to filter, warm, and moisten it; smell receptors live high up.
3. **Paranasal sinuses** (frontal, maxillary, ethmoid, sphenoid) – air-filled spaces that lighten the skull and condition air; drain into the nasal cavity.
4. **Pharynx (throat)** – three regions:

   * **Nasopharynx** (behind the nose)
   * **Oropharynx** (behind the mouth; food + air share this space)
   * **Laryngopharynx** (leads to the larynx for air or esophagus for food)
5. **Epiglottis** – a leaf-shaped flap that tilts down when you swallow so food doesn’t enter the airway.
6. **Larynx (voice box)** – contains vocal cords; the opening between them is the **glottis**.
7. **Trachea (windpipe)** – rigid tube with C-shaped cartilage rings; lined with cilia that sweep debris upward (the “mucociliary escalator”).
8. **Carina** – the tracheal split.
9. **Main bronchi** – right and left primary branches; the **right main bronchus** is shorter, wider, and more vertical (aspired objects lodge here more often).
10. **Lobar (secondary) bronchi** – one to each lung lobe (3 right, 2 left).
11. **Segmental (tertiary) bronchi** – supply bronchopulmonary segments.
12. **Conducting bronchioles → terminal bronchioles** – small airways without cartilage; still just conducting air (no gas exchange yet).
13. **Respiratory bronchioles → alveolar ducts → alveolar sacs → alveoli** – the **respiratory zone** where oxygen enters blood and carbon dioxide leaves across the ultra-thin alveolar–capillary membrane. Type II cells make **surfactant** to keep alveoli open.

**Around the lungs:**

* **Pleura:** visceral layer on the lung, parietal layer on the chest wall; a thin fluid layer lets lungs glide during breathing.
* **Diaphragm & intercostals:** main breathing muscles.

## How air travels (step-by-step)

1. **Inhale:** Diaphragm contracts and moves down, ribs lift—chest cavity expands, drawing air in.
2. **Air path:** Nostrils → nasal cavity (or mouth) → pharynx → past epiglottis → **larynx** → **trachea** → **carina** → **right/left main bronchi** → lobar bronchi → segmental bronchi → bronchioles → terminal bronchioles → **respiratory bronchioles** → **alveolar ducts** → **alveolar sacs** → **alveoli**.
3. **Gas exchange:** Oxygen diffuses from alveoli to blood; carbon dioxide diffuses from blood to alveoli.
4. **Exhale:** Diaphragm relaxes and moves up; lungs recoil and air flows out along the same path in reverse.

## Quick memory trick

**“N-N-P-L-T-B-B-b-b-A”** → Nose, Nasal cavity, Pharynx, Larynx, Trachea, Bronchi (main → lobar → segmental), bronchioles (conducting → terminal), **A**lveoli (via respiratory bronchioles & ducts).

---

If you’d like, I can add labels or callouts tailored to your study needs (e.g., “conducting vs. respiratory zone,” or a zoom-in on the vocal cords).

question: I'm studying the Flamingo model architecture, specifically the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer. Can you explain how this layer works and its components?
reference_text: The Gated XATTN-DENSE layer in Flamingo is a crucial component that combines gated cross-attention and gated feed-forward layers to process vision and language inputs. It performs self-attention on the language input and cross-attention with the vision input. The layer includes gating parameters, alpha_xattn and alpha_dense, to control the contribution of the attention and feed-forward operations. The layer outputs language features enhanced with visual information, allowing the model to process multimodal data efficiently.
generated_text:
Text (separate from the image):

# What is the Gated XATTN-DENSE layer?

In Flamingo, this is the multimodal **adapter** inserted into a frozen language model (LM) so token representations can **attend to visual latents** while keeping the LM’s original behavior largely intact. It’s a two-part block:

1. a **gated cross-attention (XATTN)** sublayer, and
2. a **gated feed-forward (“DENSE”/MLP)** sublayer, each wrapped with pre-LayerNorm and residual connections.

---

## Inputs

* **Text hidden states** (H \in \mathbb{R^{T\times d}}): current LM token embeddings.
* **Visual latents** (Z \in \mathbb{R^{M\times d_v}}): a fixed set of tokens produced by the Perceiver Resampler from one or more images/video frames.
* (Learned) **gating projections** that turn each token’s state into an element-wise gate.

---

## Step-by-step flow

### 1) Gated Cross-Attention (XATTN)

* **Pre-norm:** (\tilde H = \mathrm{LN}(H)).
* **Cross-attention:** queries (Q) come from (\tilde H); keys/values (K,V) come from (Z).
  [
  A=\mathrm{MHA}(\tilde H W_Q,\; ZW_K,\; ZW_V)
    ]
* **Gate the visual update:** compute a token-wise, channel-wise gate
  [
  g_x=\sigma(\tilde H W_{gx}+b_{gx})\in\mathbb{R^{T\times d}},
    ]
  then modulate the cross-attn output and add residually: [
  H^{(1)}=H + g_x \odot A.
    ]
  The gate lets the layer learn **how much** each token should trust vision, often starting near “closed” so initial behavior matches the base LM.

### 2) Gated DENSE (position-wise MLP)

* **Pre-norm:** (\hat H=\mathrm{LN}(H^{(1)})).
* **MLP/Dense:** (F=\phi(\hat H W_1 + b_1) W_2 + b_2) (with a standard nonlinearity (\phi), e.g., GELU).
* **Gate the MLP update:**
  [
  g_d=\sigma(\hat H W_{gd}+b_{gd}),\qquad
  H_{\text{out}}=H^{(1)} + g_d \odot F.
    ]

---

## Why the gating?

* **Stability with frozen backbones:** The LM (and typically the vision encoder) can remain frozen; new parameters are in the XATTN/DENSE paths and their gates. Gating prevents overwhelming the LM with visual signals early in training and enables smooth **modality balancing**.
* **Token-specific control:** Gates are computed **per token** and **per channel**, so some words (e.g., nouns near image mentions) can open the visual pathway more than others.
* **Regularization by design:** With gates near zero, the block reduces to an identity map, which curbs overfitting and preserves strong language priors.

---

## Placement in Flamingo

These Gated XATTN-DENSE blocks are **interleaved at several points** inside the LM stack. During inference on interleaved image–text streams, each text segment can query the relevant **cached** visual latents via the XATTN, while standard self-attention continues to handle language context.

---

## Summary of components

* **LayerNorm (pre-norm)** before each sublayer
* **Multi-Head Cross-Attention** (Q from text, K/V from visual latents)
* **Learned sigmoid gates** (g_x, g_d) (element-wise modulation)
* **Position-wise MLP (“DENSE”)**
* **Residual connections** after both sublayers

question: What is the Inception module in convolutional neural networks, and how does it work? Please explain the structure using both an image and text.
reference_text: The Inception module is a key building block in GoogLeNet, designed to capture multi-scale spatial information efficiently. It applies multiple convolution filters (1×1, 3×3, 5×5) and pooling operations in parallel to the same input, then concatenates their outputs along the depth dimension. This enables the model to learn features at different scales simultaneously. The naïve version shown here does not yet include dimensionality reduction via 1×1 convolutions before the larger filters, which was introduced later for computational efficiency.
generated_text:
# Image

*A clean diagram of Faster R-CNN with an emphasis on the Region Proposal Network (RPN) is shown above.*

# Text

**Faster R-CNN in a nutshell**

1. **Backbone feature map**
   An image passes through a CNN backbone (e.g., ResNet). The output is a dense **feature map**.

2. **Region Proposal Network (RPN)** — the key piece

* A small conv (typically **3×3**) slides over the feature map.
* At each spatial location it places **k anchors** (default boxes at multiple scales/aspect ratios).
* Two parallel 1×1 heads predict for every anchor:

  * **Objectness score** (foreground vs background)
  * **Box deltas** (tx, ty, tw, th) to refine the anchor.
* Gather all anchors, apply **box decoding + clipping**, then **Non-Maximum Suppression (NMS)** to keep the **top-N proposals** (e.g., \~200–300 at test time).
  **Purpose:** Replace slow hand-crafted proposal methods with a fast, learned, end-to-end generator of high-quality candidate regions.

3. **RoI feature extraction**
   Each proposal is projected back onto the backbone feature map and pooled to a fixed size (RoI Pool/Align).

4. **Detection head**
   Fully connected (or conv) layers output:

* **Class probabilities** (including background)
* **Per-class box refinements** (final bounding boxes)

**Training note (brief):**
RPN and detector share the backbone. A multitask loss (objectness + box regression for RPN; classification + box regression for the detector) enables joint, end-to-end learning.

question: I'm trying to understand how Mask R-CNN works for instance segmentation. How does it extend Faster R-CNN to generate masks along with bounding boxes and class labels? Please include an image and brief explanation.
reference_text: Mask R-CNN extends Faster R-CNN by adding a parallel branch for predicting object masks in addition to bounding box and class predictions. After region proposals are extracted using a Region Proposal Network (RPN), features are aligned using RoIAlign (an improved version of RoIPool), and passed into two heads: one for classification and bounding box regression, and the other for per-pixel binary mask prediction. This design enables precise instance-level segmentation for each detected object.
